channel.title: World
channel.description: The Washington Post World section provides information and analysis of breaking world news stories. In addition to our world news and video, Post World News offers discussions and blogs on major international news and economic issues.

item.title: U.S. provided intelligence that helped Ukraine sink Russian warship
item.dc:creator: Shane Harris
item.description: The United States provided Ukraine with intelligence that helped Kyiv add: identify, attack and sink the flagship of Russia’s Black Sea fleet, the Moskva, in one of the most dramatic battlefield successes of the 71-day old war, according to people familiar with the matter.

item.title: Russia-Ukraine war live updates: Mariupol plant under heavy assault as new evacuation convoy heads to site
item.dc:creator: David L. Stern
item.description: Russia ramps up attacks on Ukraine's infrastructure as Mariupol officials lose contact with remaining troops at the Azovstal steel plant.

item.title: American killed in Ukraine was a volunteer, fellow fighters say
item.dc:creator: Razzan Nakhlawi
item.description: The 22-year-old veteran believed to be the first American killed while fighting in the Ukrainian military was serving as a volunteer, not a private contractor, two fellow fighters said Thursday, contradicting earlier reports suggesting the latter.

item.title: U.S. provided intelligence that helped Ukraine sink Russian warship
item.dc:creator: Shane Harris
item.description: The United States provided Ukraine with intelligence that helped Kyiv add: identify, attack and sink the flagship of Russia’s Black Sea fleet, the Moskva, in one of the most dramatic battlefield successes of the 71-day old war, according to people familiar with the matter.

item.title: Russia-Ukraine war live updates: Mariupol plant under heavy assault as new evacuation convoy heads to site
item.dc:creator: David L. Stern
item.description: Russia ramps up attacks on Ukraine's infrastructure as Mariupol officials lose contact with remaining troops at the Azovstal steel plant.

item.title: American killed in Ukraine was a volunteer, fellow fighters say
item.dc:creator: Razzan Nakhlawi
item.description: The 22-year-old veteran believed to be the first American killed while fighting in the Ukrainian military was serving as a volunteer, not a private contractor, two fellow fighters said Thursday, contradicting earlier reports suggesting the latter.

item.title: Three people killed in attack near Tel Aviv, Israeli medics say
item.dc:creator: Steve Hendrix
item.description: The attacks were the latest in a recent string of deadly assaults on civilians, according to public safety officials and Israeli media.

item.title: Russian oligarch’s $300 million yacht seized by Fiji on behalf of U.S.
item.dc:creator: Annabelle Timsit
item.description: The Justice Department announced that Fiji executed a seizure warrant on the Amadea, a 348-foot-long luxury vessel owned by Russian oligarch Suleyman Kerimov that authorities say was “subject to forfeiture based on probable cause of violations of U.S. law.”

item.title: Ukraine says Russia is stealing grain, which could worsen food crisis
item.dc:creator: Claire Parker
item.description: Ukrainian officials say hunger is a growing threat.

item.title: Putin apologizes to Israel for Hitler comments as Zelensky slams Nazi rhetoric
item.dc:creator: Timothy Bella
item.description: The reported apology came after Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky accused Russia of using Nazi propaganda and antisemitic tropes to justify the invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: Belarusian president, a Putin ally, did not expect war to ‘drag on’
item.dc:creator: Ellen Francis
item.description: Alexander Lukashenko, close ally of Russia's Putin, said Belarus's military drills pose no threat to Ukraine: "The West can sleep peacefully."

item.title: The other Mr. Ma: Mistaken identity embodies China’s tech woes
item.dc:creator: Eva Dou
item.description: After a string of regulatory crackdowns, public crackdowns on executives and U.S. sanctions, China's tech sector is on edge.

item.title: Ukraine has accused Russian troops of rape, a tough crime to prosecute
item.dc:creator: Miriam Berger
item.description: Experts say rape is an extremely difficult crime to document and even more challenging to prosecute — especially in times of war.

item.title: At the scene of Mariupol theater tragedy, Russia prepares for a parade
item.dc:creator: Rachel Pannett
item.description: Mariupol officials say local crews, apparently working in exchange for food, are clearing streets of bodies and ordnance ahead of Victory Day.

item.title: Oligarch’s effort to broker peace falters even as it shields him from sanctions
item.dc:creator: Greg Miller
item.description: Billionaire Roman Abramovich has sought to wield influence beyond Russia’s borders to protect his empire.

item.title: An open-ended war forces one Ukrainian city to reinvent itself
item.dc:creator: Hannah Allam
item.description: Lviv is undergoing "colossal" changes to cope with wartime strains on housing, schools and services

item.title: The global stakes behind America’s abortion fight
item.dc:creator: Ishaan Tharoor
item.description: Advocates fear regression on abortion access in the United States would give momentum to illiberal forces elsewhere.

item.title: Mexico will take back more Cubans and Nicaraguans expelled by U.S.
item.dc:creator: Nick Miroff
item.description: The deal is potentially significant because the Mexican government has more latitude to carry out deportation flights to Cuba and Nicaragua, nations whose frosty relations with Washington severely limit the United States’ ability to return their citizens.

item.title: Ukrainian officials raise warnings about Russia’s Victory Day as heavy fighting continues in east
item.dc:creator: Dan Lamothe
item.description: Ukrainian officials say debris is being cleared as Russians plan to turn Mariupol into the center of “celebrations” for Victory Day on May 9.

item.title: Kremlin is targeting Ukraine resupply infrastructure, officials say
item.dc:creator: Abigail Hauslohner
item.description: The Kremlin is carrying out strikes on infrastructure that is critical to Ukraine’s efforts to resupply its forces in their defense against Russia’s invasion, Ukrainian officials and the Pentagon said.

item.title: Leader of Haitian gang behind missionary abductions is charged in U.S.
item.dc:creator: Widlore Mérancourt
item.description: Germine Joly, also known as “Yonyon,” allegedly ran 400 Mawozo from his prison cell.

item.title: Scrapping Roe would affect both sides of border, Canadian official says
item.dc:creator: Miriam Berger
item.description: Abortion is legal in Canada, though access remains scarce for many outside of urban centers.

item.title: E.U. proposes ban on Russian oil imports by end of year
item.dc:creator: Emily Rauhala
item.description: The plan, announced by European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, has been circulated to E.U. diplomats and could be approved this week.

item.title: Peru prosecutors to probe plagiarism claim against president
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: Peru’s prosecutor’s office has said it is investigating President Pedro Castillo and his wife for alleged plagiarism after a television station said an investigation showed the couple may have copied more than half the master’s thesis they co-authored

item.title: 3 Israelis killed in stabbing attack near Tel Aviv
item.dc:creator: Joseph Krauss | AP
item.description: Israeli officials say at least three people have been killed in a Palestinian stabbing attack near Tel Aviv

item.title: Mexicans recreate 1862 Cinco de Mayo victory over French
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: Residents in Mexico City marched, danced and fired blanks from muskets to mark the 160th anniversary of the 1862 victory over French troops in the nearby city of Puebla

item.title: Ukrainian troops unlikely to get easy exit from steel mill
item.dc:creator: Jamey Keaten | AP
item.description: Followng the evacuation of some civilians from a sprawling steel mill besieged by Russian forces in the port of Mariupol, attention is turning to the fate of hundreds of Ukrainian troops still inside the plant’s warren of underground tunnels and bunkers

item.title: Cardinal: Pope OK'd spending 1M euros to free kidnapped nun
item.dc:creator: Nicole Winfield | AP
item.description: A cardinal has testified that Pope Francis authorized spending up to 1 million euros to free a Colombian nun kidnapped by al-Qaida-linked militants in Mali

item.title: Australian woman missing in Mexico after child found alone
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: Authorities on Mexico’s Caribbean coast have issued an alert for a missing Australian woman whose2-year-old daughter was found wandering alone in the resort city of Cancun

item.title: Israel says Putin apologized over his FM's Holocaust remarks
item.dc:creator: Joseph Krauss | AP
item.description: Israeli Prime Minister Naftali Bennett says he accepted an apology from Russian President Vladimir Putin for controversial remarks about the Holocaust made by Moscow’s top diplomat

item.title: WHO: Nearly 15 million deaths associated with COVID-19
item.dc:creator: Maria Cheng | AP
item.description: The World Health Organization is estimating that nearly 15 million people were killed either by the coronavirus or by its impact on overwhelmed health systems in the first two years of the pandemic

item.title: Chanel jewelry boutique in Paris held up by armed men
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: A group of armed men have held up a Chanel jewelry boutique in Paris in broad daylight and escaped on motorcycles

item.title: Guinea prosecutor orders trial against ex-President Conde
item.dc:creator: Boubacar Diallo | AP
item.description: Guinea authorities say they will prosecute former President Alpha Conde and 26 of his officials for violence surrounding his bid for a controversial third term in office
